text:
I have a  `Dict{Symbol, Symbol}`, and I'd like to assemble it into a quoted expression:
```quote
  $key1 = $val1
  $key2 = $val2
  ...
end```
Is there an elegant way to do that? Right now I am doing the following to achieve it, but I can't help wondering if this is just me being a caveman... :sweat_smile:
```    init = quote end
    for x in symdict
        init = quote $init ; $(x[1]) = $(x[2]) end
    end
    init = MacroTools.flatten(init)```

elements.text: , and I'd like to assemble it into a quoted expression:
Is there an elegant way to do that? Right now I am doing the following to achieve it, but I can't help wondering if this is just me being a caveman...

init = quote end
    for x in symdict
        init = quote $init ; $(x[1]) = $(x[2]) end
    end
    init = MacroTools.flatten(init)

text:
I would probably write it like that:
```julia> d = Dict(:a => :b, :c => :d)
Dict{Symbol,Symbol} with 2 entries:
  :a => :b
  :c => :d

julia> Expr(:block, Expr.(:(=), keys(d), values(d))...)
quote
    a = b
    c = d
end```

elements.text: I would probably write it like that:

julia> d = Dict(:a => :b, :c => :d)
Dict{Symbol,Symbol} with 2 entries:
  :a => :b
  :c => :d

julia> Expr(:block, Expr.(:(=), keys(d), values(d))...)
quote
    a = b
    c = d
end

text:
Ha! Beat me to it. I had
```julia> Expr(:block, (:($k = $v) for (k, v) in Dict(:a => 1, :b => 2))...)
quote
    a = 1
    b = 2
end```

elements.text: Ha! Beat me to it. I had

julia> Expr(:block, (:($k = $v) for (k, v) in Dict(:a => 1, :b => 2))...)
quote
    a = 1
    b = 2
end

text: That works as well of course
